history.content:
Maybe checkout the Boyd-Vandenberghe textbook which is also a very good text on convex optimization. You can find a pdf here 

https://web.stanford.edu/~boyd/cvxbook/bv_cvxbook.pdf

It has a lot of problems (though not all of it in scope for 127)

Additionally, you can take a look at convex optimization course websites in other universities like 

https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~ggordon/10725-F12/hws.html

https://www.zubairkhalid.org/ee563/2020/cq04.pdf

These are a couple that I found to be helpful when I took the course. There are many more you could probably find on Google.

In terms of effort, I would say it can really vary on your own experiences with optimization as well as the scope of the class itself (which shifts depending on instructor). I personally had to put a lot of effort into the class because I had limited optimization experience when I took it last year. However, this effort has really paid off in future courses/research. So  while I'm not sure about the amount of effort to get any particular grade, really understanding the course material can really benefit you for a long time.

There aren't a lot of recent past midterms/finals on hkn or tbp for 127 prc exams and the LEG textbook only has a few prc questions (like < 10 per chapter). Other than the HWs and the Discussions, are there any other resources for more practice for 127 (specifically exams?) To comfortably get an A? How much would one have to work to get around a B? Thanks for any insight in advance.
history.subject: 127 study materials
